author: abbbbbbb
content: Hello, is there a link to the Merge runbook, and any rollback procedures? thanks ^_^

author: m.kalinin
content:
You may use https://launchpad.ethereum.org/en/merge-readiness
What do you mean by rollback?

author: abbbbbbb
content: What is the backup plan if there is any failures etc?

author: m.kalinin
content: Fix them! (fix would highly depend on the failure) The Merge is a one-way road with no roll back

author: abbbbbbb
content: thanks! Is there any discussions on scenarios and planning on what to do if X , Y, Z happens etc?

author: m.kalinin
content: We have two safe guards built into protocol: TTD override and TBH override. With the former the transition can be either delayed or accelerated, the latter allows for picking up an exact PoW block and fork off this block. Everything beyond that is client specific

author: m.kalinin
content: `block.difficulty` makes a call to `DIFFICULTY` opcode, thus it will return `prevRandao` post-Merge and should be renamed to `block.prevrandao` at some point. cc <@425279588009246720>

author: timbeiko
content: this server is for technical discussions - and censorship resistance touches a lot of these technical topics, of course. I think it's probably better to keep discussions anchored to the technical topics (in this server, to be clear), and move stuff that becomes a bit less related to <#595721451651465227>

author: paulmillr
content: Censorship resistance is technical.

author: timbeiko
content: It is, yes. This specific discussion about a relay is probably best suited for <#874767108809031740> then. Didn't want to just single you out, though: as I skimmed the channel there were ethPoW and devcon ticket messages as well üòÖ

author: paulmillr
content:
Censorship-resistance fits:

<#874767108809031740> for MEV/block censorship resistance
<#646778960830660623> for anonymous routing of some kind / TOR plans

Probably a bunch of other channels, i‚Äôm not sure if it makes sense to split the discussion instead of keeping in one place. It is important ‚Äî imo it‚Äôs much more important than PBS, Verkle trie migration, address space extension, or other 5 channels we‚Äôre having.

author: pietjepuk
content: That's all fine, but when it devolves into personal anecdotes, different government policies on the topic, etc, that's not really what this server is for I would say.

author: timbeiko
content: The challenge is channels with a "heated" topic often turn to a trashfire and are hard to keep high signal.

author: paulmillr
content: Right. I‚Äôm just frustrated no action is done regarding this, so was thinking about the channel as a signal of some sort. It‚Äôs been almost 1 months since torn got sanctioned. Developers are cruising with their stuff even though the existential threat got more pronounced.

author: pietjepuk
content: Understandable, and discussions have been had here before (and in the past as well) on the topic of censorship resistance. As long as it's kept somewhat technical it's fine. I hope you do realize there are a lot of other things that some might consider existential threats, and have been so for quite a while (EVM improvements, reducing end-user requirements of storage/computing/etc, lowering fees, etc). But you're not alone in wanting a privacy-default Ethereum

author: paulmillr
content: Makes sense: it should all be technical. However, why can‚Äôt we have a big-tent channel for censorship-resistance? We have <#847906692183359568>, <#720658991763685377>, <#731173407064064011>, others - which are fairly generic.

author: pietjepuk
content: The way it usually goes is to have _some_ technical discussions in one of the existing channels first (and e.g. an ethresear.ch post or two). And if there's a common thread forming itself, you can get a channel for that particular topic/subtopic/related topic. I don't see any use for a big-tent channel, and haven't seen a lot of technical discussions on privacy lately on anything other than PBS/block construction (which has a channel). From experience, a big-tent channel would only lead to more _non-technical_ discussions and noise for people trying to follow a topic. Nothing wrong with those types of discussions per se, but isn't really a fit for this server and its stated purposes.

author: monkeyontheloose.eth
content: <@943912959057461258> i feel ur rage bro

author: monkeyontheloose.eth
content: it's super important

author: monkeyontheloose.eth
content: don't think this is the right channel for it tho

author: paulmillr
content:
Exactly - not many technical discussions on privacy. I‚Äôve created ethresearch post, it was not popular. The channel could make people discuss it more. If they will be discussing off-topic stuff, folks could moderate the channel and warn them.

For example, i‚Äôm not familiar with block construction ‚Äî so I won‚Äôt follow the channel. I‚Äôm slightly familiar with ETH networking. But i‚Äôm very interested in all vectors of censorship in ETH. So I would just follow the channel since it‚Äôs my interest. Starting from the channel, folks like me could dive deeper into block-construction, etc, if it‚Äôs related to censorship.

In any case, if you don‚Äôt want to make it, it‚Äôs fine and just tells us a bit ETH policymaker priority. Which is: having a channel for ‚Äúverkle trie migration‚Äù and none for ‚Äúcensorship resistance‚Äù.

I will shut up since the discussion is off-topic for merge-public.

author: pietjepuk
content:
> The channel could make people discuss it more. If they will be discussing off-topic stuff, folks could moderate the channel and warn them.
If history is any indication, it doesn't work that way. It only leads to more noise, and people here really don't want to moderate additional noise.

> For example, i‚Äôm not familiar with block construction ‚Äî so I won‚Äôt follow the channel. I‚Äôm slightly familiar with ETH networking. But i‚Äôm very interested in all vectors of censorship in ETH. So I would just follow the channel since it‚Äôs my interest.
That's all fine, but I would say this server is not for learning about all types of things related to e.g. Ethereum and censorship. It really is rather focused on R&D (core development). It may feel hostile, but it e.g. isn't the place to ask "what is Ethereum doing about <X>", or to have general discussions on the topic ("Ethereum _should_ be doing <X>, or maybe <Y>").

I would say <#824798757618188339> the last few days is a good illustration of what this server is for; developers/researchers asking rather specific questions to other developers/researchers and figuring stuff out together. There are shades of grey of course.

author: paulmillr
content: If it isn‚Äôt for general discussions, why is there <#847906692183359568> with general (technical) discussions about attack vectors?

author: pietjepuk
content:
With "generic" I specifically meant the example sentences I mentioned above (more policy/governance type of things). But generic is also a rather relative term. If we pick "verkle-trie-migration",  you could split that up in the migration part, the pedersen commitment part, how to make witnesses out of it, etc.

Don't look to me for absolute rules of what is allowed or isn't on this server, or why things are the way they are. I'm also mostly just a lurker, but I have been around during some noisy periods and then it's just annoyingly hard to keep up. Just trying to prevent that from happening again, as it tends to lead to developers/researchers moving out-of-sight to less noisy places (because those _are_ needed to have the technical discussions).

author: smixxtape
content: Whats the best practice for confirming a transaction / block is confirmed/finalized after the merge. Currently pre-merge an exchange like Kraken is waiting for 20 confirmations to credit a deposit. Is that sufficient post-merge?

author: tersec
content: To be sure, wait for finalization

author: djrtwo
content: justification is revealed as `safe` which it is under normal network synchrony and >50% honesty assumptions

author: djrtwo
content: so, head (and some block depth confs) -> safe (justification) -> finalization
